metadata.title: Pregnancy and rates of Crohn’s . . . and other stories

summary: An analysis of data from a Norwegian patient register finds that pregnancy leads to a reduction in the risk of Crohn’s disease.

Among women whose youngest child was 0-4 years old, rates of diagnosis of Crohn’s disease were roughly a third lower than those in women of a similar age without children (Am J Epidemiol doi:10.1093/aje/kwz285).
There was no reduction in the occurrence of Crohn’s disease among fathers.
The question is whether this is a biological effect of the pregnancy, something to do with the use or non-use of oral contraception, or a …

Results: An analysis of data from a Norwegian patient register finds that pregnancy leads to a reduction in the risk of Crohn’s disease.

Among women whose youngest child was 0-4 years old, rates of diagnosis of Crohn’s disease were roughly a third lower than those in women of a similar age without children (Am J Epidemiol doi:10.1093/aje/kwz285).
There was no reduction in the occurrence of Crohn’s disease among fathers.
Conclusion: The question is whether this is a biological effect of the pregnancy, something to do with the use or non-use of oral contraception, or a …
